article.title: Comment on "Franson Interference Generated by a Two-Level System"

multiple_choice_question.text: The authors of the commented article claim that the reported visibility "goes beyond the classical limit of 50% and approaches the limit of violation of Bell\'s inequalities (70.7%)." What is the main point of contention raised in this comment?
choices: The reported visibility of 66% is not high enough to definitively claim a violation of Bell\'s inequalities.
The authors incorrectly assume a 100% detection efficiency (η = 1) when calculating the 70.7% visibility bound.
Franson interferometry is not a suitable experimental setup for testing violations of Bell\'s inequalities.
The use of a two-level semiconductor quantum dot introduces inherent limitations that prevent a genuine violation of local realism.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the comment, what is the main reason why the 70.7% visibility bound for violating Bell\'s inequalities is unattainable in the Franson interferometer, even ideally?
choices: The use of frequency-filtered scattered light inherently limits the achievable visibility.
Imperfections in detectors and couplings inevitably reduce the effective detection efficiency.
The post-selection step in Franson interferometry necessitates discarding approximately half of the recorded photons.
The two-level nature of the quantum dot used in the experiment imposes a fundamental limitation on the achievable visibility.

multiple_choice_question.text: What alternative approach does the comment suggest for potentially observing a genuine violation of Bell\'s inequalities in a similar experimental setup?
choices: Increasing the efficiency of the detectors used in the experiment to approach η = 1.
Replacing the Franson interferometer with a different experimental setup more suitable for Bell tests.
Employing a three-setting chained Bell inequality instead of the CHSH Bell inequality.
Utilizing a different type of quantum dot with properties that allow for higher visibilities.
